Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2011 03:47PM Wabbit wrote: I had quite a bit of bruising after my surgery and I do remember large patches of it turning yellow before it went away. I don't remember about the getting 'brighter' part ... it's been several years ago now.  Is it maybe getting lighter? If it is really making you worry maybe you could go to the emergency room or an urgent care center and have somebody take a quick look at it?  There is enough to deal with going through all this without having to sit around and worry about something too.    (((hugs)))
Posts.Title: Help - Bright Yellow Skin!!!!! A_pallens barbe1958

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2012 07:14AM Wabbit wrote: You need to make sure your mother has a follow up appointment scheduled with her breast surgeon.  I believe mine was a week after my surgery and I was told to call the surgeon or go to the emergency room if I had problems that needed to be addressed before that.  So yes ... they do pretty much just send you home and leave you to deal with it all yourself. She will most likely be referred to an oncologist to discuss any further treatment required.    In terms of personal support I agree that the ACS or the social worker at her hospital could give you or her information about peer support groups available.  And if she has a computer this is an excellent place to come and talk to other women with breast cancer. Best wishes to you both.

It all feels weird for sure.

Posts.Title: I really need wisdom on what to do. Elibet AJ251

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 07:14AM Wabbit wrote: martygra ... you are getting ready to jump on the merry-go-round of tests and treatment and I just wanted to send you some (((hugs)))  Like you I had about a 3cm lump, ER+ and also had a SNB and then did chemo to shrink the tumor prior to surgery.  That was 5 years ago ... and I'm fine now.   Mostly I just wanted to let you know that although this will take over a big chunk of your life for a while ... you will get through this and get a normal life back.  The fact that your employer is being supportive is wonderful!   The only advice I have is to not try to be superwoman ... you are going to be fatigued as a result of the chemo and then surgery.  Pamper yourself all you can while you are going through this!
Posts.Title: Off to the doctor today. martygra martygra

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2011 06:32AM Wabbit wrote: Just checking on you martygra ... hope your SNB surgery went well.
Posts.Title: Off to the doctor today. martygra martygra

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2011 10:49AM Wabbit wrote: Glad to hear it went well ... minimal pain and no drain is good.  Somebody on here once made a statement about all this that "you eat this elephant one bite at a time" and I liked that imagery.  You just got another bite done.  Don't be real surprised if they send you for a PET scan next if they haven't already.  I just mention that because when they sent me it really freaked me out and had me thinking the worst.  Turns out it is routine and something many oncs like to do if they can get insurance approval for one.  Do you know when you start your chemo or what kind you are having?  And hey ... you have good reason to be tired.  I think you should pamper yourself now and if you don't feel like doing anything just don't do it.  (((hugs)))
Posts.Title: Off to the doctor today. martygra martygra

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 09:13AM Wabbit wrote: Glad to hear you talked to your boss and that he is being so helpful!  People will take their cues from you I think as to how much you want to talk about it right now.     I don't know about anybody else but I didn't want to talk to anybody about it until I had come to grips with it myself either.  Once treatment started it was easier.  And honestly even after that I got to be very good at changing the subject when friends brought it up.  You are certainly normal ... and any way you want to handle it is the right way for you and that's what you should do.   And it's also normal to be totally obsessed with it right now and unable to concentrate on much of anything else.  Time is your friend.    Hope your treatment goes well with minimal side effects!
Posts.Title: Off to the doctor today. martygra martygra

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2011 12:12AM Wabbit wrote: Glad to hear that your surgery went well and negative nodes is excellent news.   Now just take it easy and pamper yourself a bit ... you deserve it!
Posts.Title: Greetings From the Other Side (post op) Michele_T NancyJill

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2011 11:36AM - edited Nov 15, 2011 11:39AM by Wabbit I think we have to be very careful with statistics of any kind.  A 5% difference in a study means that out of a room full of 100 women 5 more will recur or advance to mets without a treatment.  The devil is in the details ... and the detail is who is going to be one of those 5.  And the truth is that we don't know.  Logic says that if you have a small, low grade tumor you are less likely to be one of those 5 - and if you have a larger, high grade tumor you are more likely to be in the 5.  But ... we have seen women on these boards recur and advance who were in both categories. There is much we don't know also.     Personally I get concerned when I see women declining treatment based on what sounds more like outdated and exaggerated fears about chemo and radiation than anything else.  Avoiding temporary side effects can result in much much worse down the road.   So ... I agree ... get all the information you can and look at your individual situation realistically to make your decisions.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed~information & choices! Miles2Go otter

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2011 10:51AM - edited Nov 17, 2011 10:53AM by Wabbit I think you are preaching to the choir here.  The people who research enough to find this board and then participate in it are already the ones who are actively looking for information. Honestly, when you keep posting the same thing over and over it starts to look like you think we are a bunch of bobbleheads who don't already know we have choices.   Or aren't smart enough to make good ones or something.  I think you can stop worrying about us ... we get it :)
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed~information & choices! Miles2Go otter

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2012 10:29AM Wabbit wrote: Sounds like they have seen something but aren't sure it is abnormal.  Glad you are having a follow-up with a surgeon to check it out further.  Better safe than sorry.  Even in cases where biopsy is strongly advised about 80% turn out to be benign thingies so the odds are in your favor. It's true that most of the stories you will read here will be the ones who did turn out to have breast cancer.  We are the ones who stay on this board.  The women with benign findings get their results and don't post anymore.  So try to remember that as you read. It's hard not to worry ... impossible really ...so I hope they can get you all tested soonest.  All fingers and toes crossed that they do a thorough job of checking out whatever it is ... and that you get the all clear!
Posts.Title: Just got my call from the nurse and.. StephanieMO3 Mebelissa

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2013 06:14PM Wabbit wrote: IMO you should get a second opinion any time you feel like you don't totally understand what is going on, are unsure about the treatment being recommended, or are not comfortable with the doctor you are dealing with for any reason. I liked and trusted my surgeon immediately and she was very good at answering my questions.  Thus I personally did not feel the need for a second opinion from another surgeon.  I guess the answer to your question is that you should do what you are comfortable with.  Best wishes to you as you start down the path of surgery and treatment.
Posts.Title: When should we get a second opinion? JohnLeo InspiredbyDolce

Posts.Content: May 2, 2012 09:49AM Wabbit wrote: I bet I'm the only one who had a (very young) nurse who was more nervous about removing it than I was.  She even blurted out that she always had (other nurse) do those because 'she didn't like to hurt people'.  Then kind of froze when she realized what she said. I assured her that I had taken Tylenol to prepare and we would be fine.  We did the breathe in and out thing and it didn't hurt a bit.  I couldn't be mad at her because it was actually sweet of her to care.  Or maybe my 'Mom' instinct kicked in. So it turned out to be a bc 'story' and we had a laugh about how she probably should never ever say that again.
Posts.Title: Drain removal with no pain meds?! Stormynyte SerendipiTea

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2012 10:07AM - edited Aug 14, 2012 10:16AM by Wabbit I felt the same way so I sure don't think you are silly :)  I wore a turban kind of hat that day and they didn't say a word about taking it off ... they just put their cap thing over it. So probably the trick is to wear something the surgical cap will fit over with no problem.  Best wishes for your treatment and surgery to go smoothly.  I did find that it was nice to not have to mess with trying to do something with hair after the surgery by the way.
Posts.Title: Hair question and hospital pamelahope pamelahope

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2011 09:10AM Wabbit wrote: There is a federal Breast and Cervical Cancer Treatment Program for those with no insurance.  The Program is actually run by each State for their residents so you will need to check with your State Health Department to find out about eligibility and how to get in the program.  Or perhaps one of your medical providers will have this information.  Or you should be able to Google it along with the name of your State to get some contact information. Do check this out ... if you are eligible Medicaid will be available to you to pay for all of your treatment. (((hugs)))
Posts.Title: I don't know what to do Helen-Ann Survivorwoman

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2011 10:14PM - edited Nov 29, 2011 10:17PM by Wabbit  I had 4 AC treatments prior to surgery to shrink a tail on my tumor away from the chest wall.  So I got to watch/feel my almost 4cm tumor shrink and a second smaller one totally disappeared.    My side effects were a serious case of the blahs ... a foggy head, a queasy stomach and food and drink tasted horrible the week after treatment.  The next 2 weeks were relatively normal ... just fatigue if I tried to do too much.  My blood counts were always back up in time for my next treatment and I did not need the Neulasta shots.  I lost my hair and after all the stressing I did about it beforehand it was not as bad as I expected either.  My side effects were all temporary and the only thing I can even blame on 'chemo brain' is that I tend to make more spelling errors now. I do think that being able to see physically that it was working made it easier to put up with the side effects.  And after the first treatment I knew what to expect and could prepare and plan accordingly. I'm concerned about some of the stuff I'm seeing on the board lately because I think some of it is dangerous.  I've read some comments about chemo being a sledgehammer when a flyswatter would do ... but I think the old cliche about not bringing a slingshot to a gun fight is more applicable.  YMMV   My oncologist is one of the ones who gives the chemo drugs in her office facility.  I do want to mention that she did not recommend that I do any more chemo after surgery.  I think if it was all about profit for her ... as some here have suggested ... she would have recommended doing one of the Taxol type drugs also and she did not. Cancer is not some fuzzy little thing to be played around with.  It is capable of much much worse than any chemo side effects in my opinion.   I'm glad I did it.

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2011 09:57AM Wabbit wrote: Judy67 ... your experience with the oncotype shows that they are making progress in determining who  will benefit from chemo at the earlier stages.  Probably did not feel good to learn that score - but as you say it is so much better to know so you can do what is necessary to beat this thing.  Hope your treatment goes well and is as easy on you as possible. Now ... do you have a cat?  a dog?    The silliness is just a sideline here.  Hope more people will chime in with their comments in response to the actual thread subject :)
Posts.Title: Chemo and Breast Cancer - Another Perspective PlantLover LtotheK

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2011 11:44AM - edited Nov 30, 2011 11:48AM by Wabbit I second what PlantLover said. I was terrified of the whole idea of chemo ... but I didn't really know anything other than it's bad 'reputation'.  The actual experience for me was simply just not that bad at all ... not even close to what I expected.  The last thing I needed from this board was anybody playing on those fears, saying that chemo would most likely kill me and trying to talk me out of a treatment that I absolutely needed.  I'm glad I did not encounter that back then.  I like to think I would have done it anyway but who knows ... we all tend to hear what we want to hear and at that point in time I was defintely vulnerable. What I did find was women sharing their own experiences and confirming that they had done it and got through it and that I could do it too.  And sharing their side effects also ... which gave me an idea of what to prepare for. Bless them all! So ... I hope this thread can do what PlantLover intended and some more members will put their stories on here.  The good, bad and even the ugly ... but the truth.
Posts.Title: Chemo and Breast Cancer - Another Perspective PlantLover LtotheK

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2011 12:51PM - edited Dec 6, 2011 12:54PM by Wabbit I'm reading the same anti-chemo stuff here that has already been posted many times on the Alternative thread.  This topic was started to give the other side of the story ... and most likely in response to the Alternatives request that we take our views elsewhere.  Nor is the topic of this thread "Stage 1 and chemo'.  Thus I understand PlantLovers frustration.  I was treated 5 years ago.  I also have several friends who had breast cancer before me.  3 of them were Stage 1 and none were even recommended to have chemo.  The exceptions are generally based on young age, triple negative and HER2+ status.   Stage I and Stage II women who have received conflicting recommendations re chemo have been freely posting about it and discussing it on this board for years.  Each case is individual and needs to be considered on that basis IMO. ETA ... LOL.  A lot can happen while you are writing oh so seriously :)  My clinic will feature cats.  Their tongues will do a much better job of removing any impurities and their purrs have been proven to reduce stress.

ETA:  Answered my own question ... www.burtongoldberg.com/   Seems he has a Doctor of Humanities Hon. - from Capital University of Integrated Medicine.  I think the Hon. part means he didn't study there they just honored him with it.
